posts.cooked: I’m not on the cad team for our robot but I have been doing electrical work and I’ve gotten really annoyed at having to find the random nooks and crannies to stick things like spark maxes or having to figure out how to fit the main electricals in the belly pan or having to make entirely new parts to run cables up the elevator because cad didn’t do anything for that. As such, what tools/ideas/techniques can I give the cad team besides just telling them “please please please cad out the electrical”?

posts.name: Drakxii
posts.cooked:
First for the motor controllers and main electrical systems they should be on the CAD.

Second for the wires, add a review step for electrical to look over the design before you start production, so you can see if any holes need to made to run the wires, and/or make the CADers run the wires so they can feel the pain.

posts.name: Noah Kirby
posts.cooked: Personally i would never run wires in cad from each individual component. What i prefer to do is group wires. So all the right drivetrain wires will be rendered as 1 wire, same for left, and just ignore can or render 1 wire to every motor controller.

for the most part that will likely work fine as those seperate wires will all be doing the same thing anyway. I just need the cadders to be prepared to have a solution for annoying wiring things like an elevator or something like that.

posts.name: Drakxii
posts.cooked:
Oh I would never suggest CAD wires (well unless we are talking something super small like a rocket or sub) but just having the electrical team look over the CAD and give feedback BEFORE it’s used to make parts.

Too many teams “finish” their robots then give it to electrical team members to wire it up without allowing them to be involved with the design.

posts.name: Brian Wagg
posts.cooked:
I dont think the suggestion here is to physically CAD/draw the wire runs, but add a design review into a teams design process where those reponsible for installing/running the electrical can give input before parts are cut/finalized.

Of course, that feedback needs to be listened to and respected by the CAD team. If that’s an issue (CAD members dismissing the importance of planning electrical and ignoring the expertise of their electrical team), then I’d encourage you ask a mentor on your team to help mediate those discussions.

posts.name: wgorgen
posts.cooked:
SammyPants:

what tools/ideas/techniques can I give the cad team besides just telling them “please please please cad out the electrical”?

How do you guys do your primary electrical components? Do you locate them in a central location like a belly pan or electrical panel?

We had good luck by having a few of the non-cadders layout the actual boxes on a whiteboard that was laid flat on a build table. They located them in a logical fashion using actual components. The connection between the battery and the PDH used actual 4GA wire as well. The students taped off the shape of the belly pan including the structural support rails that were going to be present in this zone. Once they had all the components laid out in locations that they liked, they traced them with a dry erase marker and labeled each outline. Then they took a picture and showed it to the CAD group. The CAD group put the components into their model and then were able to CAD the belly pan with the attachment holes for these parts such that we would not need to drill anything during assembly.

We did this during week 1 while the CADDers were busy with concepts but we had not gotten to the prototyping stage.

It was very successful. Especially since we built a small frame this year and space was tight.

posts.name: Noah Kirby
posts.cooked: Yeah. Our electrical captain hates me for it because, since we are a small team, i (programming captain) am heavily involved in the design process early on (what else would programming do) so i specifically learned everything about electrical so i could give input during initial design on behalf of electrical. I end up stealing all her projects because im bored without a robot to program

posts.name: Chris Herzog
posts.cooked:
wgorgen:

We had good luck by having a few of the non-cadders layout the actual boxes on a whiteboard that was laid flat on a build table. They located them in a logical fashion using actual components. The connection between the battery and the PDH used actual 4GA wire as well.

This is a solid approach.

I especially like taking the heavy power wiring into account.  You can easily mount something but when trying to run 4ga wire, you find out that you ended up too close to an edge or another component to be able to wire it appropriately.

The CAD for all of our major electrical components is readily available so I’ve been a big advocate to include those in the overall design with input from the folks that have experience dealing with the various devices to provide input on mounting, orientation, wireability, etc.

I like what you are doing.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Doin' robot stuff... [ FRC 2151 + 3061 | Ri3D Redux '23 | RIP 4292 & 4241 ]

posts.custom_user_title: Doin' robot stuff... [ FRC 2151 + 3061 | Ri3D Redux '23 | RIP 4292 & 4241 ]

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked:
wgorgen:

How do you guys do your primary electrical components? Do you locate them in a central location like a belly pan or electrical panel?

There is no single or “right” way.  Some components in the belly pan are common, but teams also mount components on a “brain” pan (belly pan facing the carpet), or on multiple electrical panels that could be mounted in almost any orientation or location.  The radio is usually mounted higher on the robot to minimize signal loss.  Spark Maxes are often mounted on manipulators to avoid having to extend the motor sensor ribbon wire.  Sensors are almost always electronic components and could mount in unusual places.  The choice of where to mount electronics is influenced heavily by the design of the robot, which varies each season.

Definitely CAD all electrical components, including sensors and cameras.  CAD and fabricate your parts with mounting holes for the components, even if you don’t use them.  We like to use 3M Dual Lock to fasten many of the electrical components (never the main breaker or power distribution) for quick removal and replacement, but it’s nice to have the mounting holes there to see exactly where each component should be placed.

Mocking up component layout on a whiteboard, a cardboard model of the drive base, or even a prototype of the drive base and possibly other mechanisms is a fine idea.  However, it’s even easier to set the layout in CAD if you have a robot model already underway.  If your build and CAD students are in completely disjoint sets, it might take a bit of coordination to get all needed parties together to run through the layout options in CAD, but that’s not an insurmountable hurdle.

I’m not a fan of putting wires in CAD.  It is essential, though, to think ahead about the needed wire pathways given all the component locations, and to CAD holes or openings in panels, rails, supports, etc. to be able to route and secure the wires.  Be as generous as possible with the area of openings you provide.  Parts need to be structurally sound, but the more opening area you provide, the more chance you have to alter your original wiring concept without hacking parts and you’ ll save weight too.

posts.name: Chris_Elston
posts.cooked:
We aren’t the best at doing Electrical Drawing every year, but when we do, we use AutoCAD Electrical to represent the robot system in a professional drawing set following an industrial panel wiring set. The student that drew these drawings, now uses AutoCAD Electrical at her place of employment now as a Controls Engineer. When she was interning there, the engineering manager could not believe a high school student knew how to use AutoCAD Electrical already and was impressed with her skill set. Primary reason why she’s now an Engineer at one of our sponsors.

Here is the best set I could find in the archives. There is a DWG drawing and a PDF export to take a look if you like. It follows page number conventions and wire numbers which are always used so you can find what page the wire is on just by looking at the number on the wire.

Take a look here: https://yrginc.box.com/s/nnnocl17igcxp7ey75hk891gihuj4m7x

posts.name: wgorgen
posts.cooked:
paulonis:

There is no single or “right” way. Some components in the belly pan are common, but teams also mount components on a “brain” pan (belly pan facing the carpet), or on multiple electrical panels that could be mounted in almost any orientation or location.

I agree. But if you use some sort of dedicated location, you are probably going to fabricate a panel of some sort for mounting. Being able to cut the holes in the board for all the components is nice to do when you are fabricating the panel. And, in order to do that, you need to CAD them (or at least lay it out ahead of time with templates if you are going to hand drill the holes.

So my point was that, as a way of encouraging the CAD team to actually CAD the components, you can point out that it helps the fabrication of the panel and the subsequent assembly of the robot.

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked:
SammyPants:

I just need the cadders to be prepared to have a solution for annoying wiring things like an elevator or something like that.

It is important to know who is responsible for robot design.  Depending on the team, those who are the best at operating the CAD software are not necessarily those who are best at and responsible for conceiving and optimizing the robot design.  If someone doing CAD has little or no idea how an elevator or turret or arm is actually going to operate, they won’t have the knowledge to include cable carriers or wire loom into the model or even plan for where wire and pneumatic tubing needs to go and how long it needs to be.  Ideally, there are mentors and experienced students continuously connecting the dots between conceptual design, lessons from prototyping, and CAD.

It’s easy for almost anyone to grab the Thrifty Bot elevator model from public Onshape and drop it into their own robot model.  That doesn’t mean that they are capable of designing the robot.  Make sure you have designers guiding CAD if your lead designer is not also doing the CAD.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
Yes!

CAD serves the design process. It is not the whole design process. No team members and few mentors would have done design work when CAD was not in common use. From time to time, I have reminded the CAD group that a robot without a control system is “just a piece of sculpture”.

The approach I have guided my teams to use is to start by making a list the types and quantities of the control system parts then decide what area(s) they should be installed, taking into account the wire routing and access for construction, maintenance, modification, and inspection. Next, they estimate the size of the various control system panels and work with the CAD group to reserve the space in the design. As soon as the control panel sizes and shapes are agreed upon, the electrical group starts construction. They pre-test the panels before they are installed in the robot.

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
Board Bottom 1920×1080 66.4 KB

Board Bottom 1920×1080 66.4 KB

Board Bottom 1920×1080 66.4 KB

Sensors and motors are both mechanical and electrical, so it’s especially important to do these carefully.  Everything else in the electronics has to go somewhere, and it makes a large difference.  The battery is heavy and has to be easily changed, plus it has to stay put.  Etc.  Etc.  This stuff is part of the robot design, and needs to be handled in whatever process a team is using.

posts.name: Elliot S
posts.cooked:
To all the CADders out there, for the love of god, please put the darn BATTERY in the CAD!

DeFeNiTly no personal experience with almost putting parts on the robot that interfere with the battery

posts.name: marshall
posts.cooked:
ElliotS:

To all the CADders out there, for the love of god, please put the darn BATTERY in the CAD!

Picking on this.

We try hard to avoid the use of CAD as a verb.  We try to teach that the correct word is “designing”.  Designers use CAD software.

This helps emphasize that design comes from design requirements, like putting in the battery.

Does this really matter?  No. We aren’t strict about it but when someone says “CADing”, it enables us a small bit of course and expectation correction and better cross-functional communication between sub-groups working on differing aspects of the robot.
